constructs.name: procrastination
constructs.description: The tendency to delay or avoid tasks despite knowing it will have negative consequences

constructs.name: stress
constructs.description: Perceived psychological stress and pressure from responsibilities

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Quality and duration of sleep, affecting cognitive resources

constructs.name: digital_distraction
constructs.description: Time spent on non-productive digital media consumption

constructs.name: self_efficacy
constructs.description: Belief in one's ability to accomplish tasks and goals

edges.description: Low self-efficacy leads to task avoidance
Procrastination increases stress from accumulating tasks

messages.content: You are an expert in causal inference and structural causal models...
Research question: What factors drive procrastination in knowledge workers?
I'll analyze the causal mechanisms behind procrastination. Let me validate my proposed latent model.
messages.reasoning: The user wants to understand procrastination drivers. I should identify key theoretical constructs from psychology literature: stress, sleep quality, digital distraction, self-efficacy, and workload. These map to well-established theories (ego depletion, temporal motivation theory).

messages.content: The latent model has been validated. Here is the final causal structure with 6 constructs and 8 edges...
messages.reasoning: The model passed validation. The DAG is acyclic in the contemporaneous subgraph, with feedback loops captured via lagged edges.

context: Stage 1a proposes a latent causal model based on domain knowledge alone. The model specifies theoretical constructs and their causal relationships. Assumption A4 (acyclicity) requires the contemporaneous subgraph to be a DAG. Feedback loops are modeled as lagged effects across time steps (A3 Markov property).
